chief.note: Commissioned to Central America; declined appointment. Commissioned during a recess of the Senate.
Commissioned to Central America; did not present credentials in Costa Rica. Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Feb 9, 1854.

ended.note: Notified Govt. of Costa Rica by note from Releajo, Nicaragua, May 20, 1859, of termination of his mission

chief.note: Accredited also to Nicaragua; resident at Managua.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Jan 24, 1860. Accredited also to Nicaragua; resident at Managua.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on July 22, 1861.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Jan 11, 1867.

ended.note: Notified Government of Costa Rica by note from Amapala, Honduras, Jan 31, 1879, that he had resigned

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Dec 10, 1873. Commissioned to “the Central American States” but accredited individually to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua; resident at Guatemala.
Officially recognized on Dec 25, 1879. Commissioned to “the Central American States” but accredited individually to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua; resident at Guatemala.

ended.note: Promoted to Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary

chief.note: Presented credentials the same day as Minister Resident and as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary. Commissioned to “the Central American States” but accredited individually to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua; resident at Guatemala.

ended.note: Transmitted recall by note on or shortly before

chief.note: Commissioned to “the Central American States” but accredited individually to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua; resident at Guatemala.
Commissioned to “the Central American States” but accredited individually to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua; resident at Guatemala.
Commissioned to “the Central American States” but accredited individually to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua; resident at Guatemala.
Also accredited to El Salvador and Nicaragua; resident at Managua. Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Dec 23, 1891.
Accredited also to El Salvador and Nicaragua; resident at Managua. Transmitted credentials by note from Managua on this date.

ended.note: Recommissioned to a different combination of countries

chief.note: Commissioned as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and El Salvador; resident at San Jose.
Commissioned as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Nicaragua and Costa Rica; resident at San Jose.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Dec 10, 1908.

ended.note: Normal relations interrupted, Jan 27, 1917; new Government of Costa Rica still unrecognized by the U.S. when Hale left Costa Rica, Apr 19, 1917

chief.note: Stewart Johnson was serving as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim when Legation San Jose was closed, Dec 5, 1918. The Legation was reopened Oct 15, 1920 with John F. Martin, Jr., as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim. Walter C. Thurston served in that capacity, Jan. 1921-Mar. 1922.
Did not serve under this appointment.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Jan 15, 1934.
Took oath of office, but died in the U.S. before proceeding to post.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Dec 9, 1947.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Jan 26, 1954.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned after confirmation on Dec 3, 1954.

Hinton was commissioned during a recess of the Senate as Ambassador to Panama, Jan 2, 1990, and presented his credentials there on Jan 9, 1990 (see under Panama). The following officers served as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim: Robert O. Homme (Mar-Jul 1993), Donald Harrington (Jul-Aug 1993), and Joseph Beceila (Aug 1993-Oct 1994).

Nomination of July 9, 2014, not acted upon by the Senate. Re-nominated February 5, 2015. The following officers served as charges d’affaires ad interim: Gonzalo Gallegos (June 2013-February 2015), Ray Perrin (February 2015-).
Not commissioned; nomination tabled by the Senate.
Not commissioned; nomination withdrawn before the Senate acted upon it.
The Legation was reopened Oct 15, 1920 with John F. Martin, Jr., as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim.
Not commissioned; nomination of Apr 29, 1974 was not acted upon by the Senate.
was serving as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim when Legation San Jose was closed, Dec 5, 1918
